bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 51 (Thursday, March 26, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. VEASEY:H.R. 1645.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Commerce Clause (Art. 1. sec. 8 cl. 3)Necessary and Proper Clause (Art.1 Sec. 8 cl. 18)[Page H2112]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Highways and Transit.
Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

item.name: Urban and suburban affairs and development

summary.text:
Transportation for Elderly and Disabled Individuals Act of 2015

This bill revises a special rule granting the Department of Transportation authority to make urbanized area formula grants to states or designated entities to finance the operating cost of equipment and facilities for use in public transportation.

These grants may also be used for public transportation systems that operate a specified number of buses in general public demand response service during peak hours.

bill.title: Transportation for Elderly and Disabled Individuals Act of 2015

item.title: Transportation for Elderly and Disabled Individuals Act of 2015
To amend title 49, United States Code, with respect to urbanized area formula grants, and for other purposes.
Transportation for Elderly and Disabled Individuals Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Highways and Transit.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
